summary: a large number of PEDV infections occurred unexpectedly in many Korean pig farms, which had a significant economic impact on swine farms. the PEDV genome is composed of at least seven open reading frames (ORFs), encoding three non-structural proteins (ORF1a, 1b, and ORF3) and four structural proteins; spike (S), envelope, membrane (M), and nucleocapsid (N) proteins. the N protein binds to viral RNA and provides a structural basis for the helical nucleocapsid [6]. the new mutant PEDV isolates will allow study of PED pathogenesis, effects of disinfectants, and the development of antigenic or serological diagnostic assays. a live-attenuated or inactivated vaccine to prevent PED outbreaks. small intestinal tissues were used to generate a 10% homogenate. the supernatant was filtered through a 0.45 m membrane. the cells were cultured in DMEM supplemented with antibiotics. if no CPEs were observed 5 days after harvesting the supernatant, the cells were fixed in 80% cold acetone and subjected to an immunofluorescence assay (IFA) if no CPEs were detected, the sample was considered negative for the virus. the eluted RNA was subjected to conventional reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) using the i-TGEV/PEDV detection kit (iNtRON Biotechnology, Korea) the PCR products were visualized via 1.8% agarose gel electrophoresis and ethidium bromide staining. RT-PCR was performed in a reaction mixture containing 10 L denatured RNA, 1 L each primer (50 pmol), 10 L 5 buffer (12.5 mM MgCl2), 2 L dNTP mix, 2 L enzyme mix (reverse transcriptase and Taq polymerase) and 24 L distilled water (Qiagen, Germany) the cycling profile consisted of cDNA synthesis at 42°C for 30 min. the sequences of purified plasmids were analyzed by using the MJ Research PTC-225 Peltier Thermal Cycler and ABI PRISM BigDye Terminator Cycle Sequencing kits with AmpliTaq DNA polymerase. the fluorescently labeled fragments were purified from the unincorporated terminators by applying an ethanol precipitation protocol. two pigs were orally administered a 1 mL dose of 103.0 TCID50/mL QIAP1401-P70 via 5 mL pipette. the remaining two pigs received no treatment. pigs were monitored daily for clinical signs of PEDV infection. small intestinal tissues were used to generate a 10% homogenate. the supernatant was filtered through a 0.45 m membrane. the cells were cultured in DMEM supplemented with antibiotics. if no CPEs were observed 5 days after harvesting the supernatant, the vero cells were fixed in 80% cold acetone and subjected to an immunofluorescence assay (IFA) if no CPEs were detected, the sample was considered negative for the virus. eluted RNA was subjected to conventional reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) using the i-TGEV/PEDV detection kit (iNtRON Biotechnology, Korea) the PCR products were visualized via 1.8% agarose gel electrophoresis and ethidium bromide staining. RT-PCR was performed in a reaction mixture containing 10 L denatured RNA, 1 L each primer (50 pmol), 10 L 5 buffer (12.5 mM MgCl2), 2 L dNTP mix, 2 L enzyme mix (reverse transcriptase and Taq polymerase) and 24 L distilled water. the PCR products were visualized via 1.8% agarose gel electrophoresis. the sequences of purified plasmids were analyzed by using the MJ Research PTC-225 Peltier Thermal Cycler and ABI PRISM BigDye Terminator Cycle Sequencing kits. single-pass sequencing was performed for each template by using universal primers (e.g., SP6 and T7) the fluorescently labeled fragments were purified from the unincorporated terminators by applying an ethanol precipitation protocol. two pigs were orally administered a 1 mL dose of 103.0 TCID50/mL QIAP1401-P70 via 5 mL pipette. the remaining two pigs received no treatment. pigs were monitored daily for clinical signs of PEDV infection. two PEDV isolates, designated QIAP1401 and QIAP1402, grew successfully in vero cells inoculated with small intestinal samples from piglets from the Jeju-do pig farms. clear CPEs were observed in the QIAP1401 and QIAP1402 isolates after the second passage. titer increased continuously until passage 70. vero cells were infected with the QIAP1401 or QIAP1402 isolates. titers according to number of the porcine epidemic diarrhea virus passages. the similarities of the PEDV S gene nucleotide sequences were 99.6% to 99.7% among the Korean isolates obtained after 2013. alignment of the deduced amino acid sequences showed 99.4% to 99.7% similarity among the Korean PEDV strains obtained after 2013. two piglets were orally administered the QIAP1401-P70 strain. another two piglets were housed together with the inoculated piglets. one of the control piglets died of dehydration at 4 DPI. the remaining three piglets died of dehydration at 5 and 6 DPI. several cytoplasmic vacuoles were observed in intestinal epithelial cells following hematoxylin and eosin staining (20) (A); brown staining, indicating a positive reaction, was identified by immunohistochemistry (20) (B) seven growing, 11-week-old, PEDV-seronegative pigs were administered the same PEDV strain and housed in a compartment. the QIAP1401 strain was serially passaged 70 times in vero cells. the viral titers of QIAP1401-P10, -P40, and -P70 cultured in roller bottles were 106.5, 106.8, and 107.0 TCID50/mL. PEDV particles from the QIAP1401 strain purified by gradient sucrose density centrifugation were examined by EM. the viral particles were 80 to 120 nm in diameter with crown-shaped projections. morphological appearance typical of Coronaviridae. the phylogenetic tree was constructed based on aligned nucleotide sequences obtained by using the neighbor-joining method. the complete S, ORF3, M, and N genes were sequenced after passages 3, 20, 40, and 60, respectively. no deletions were detected in the four structural proteins after 60 passages. all feces obtained from the four piglets at 1 to 6 DPI were positive for PEDV as determined by both RT-PCR and the rapid detection kit (panel A in Fig. 5). the dead piglets were necropsied on the day they died and showed shortened and fused small intestinal villi on microscopic examination. the PEDV antigen in feces was not detected at 11 DPI in growing pigs. a total of 669 cases of the disease occurred between 2000 and 2015. two large epidemics were observed in 2003 and 2014. one of the new PEDV isolates has been used to develop a vaccine candidate for live and inactivated PEDV vaccines. new vaccines are needed because the PEDV vaccine based on the SM98 or DR13 strains might be less related antigenically to the re-emerged PEDV strains. the viral titer of QIAP1401 reached 107.0 TCID50/mL by passage 70, indicating that the QIAP1401-P70 strain was PEDV-seronegative 3-day-old piglets and 11-week-old growing pigs were administered the QIAP1401-P70 strain orally to investigate the pathogenicity of the strain. all four of the 3-day-old piglets shed the virus in their feces, developed severe watery diarrhea from 1 to 6 DPI, and died at 4, 5 or 6 DPI. the QIAP1401 strain is strongly pathogenic to 3-day-old piglets. it could be used as a challenge strain to examine the efficacy of inactivated PEDV vaccines.
